comments.html:
Last week: tried to get documentation from Alcatel and Huawei. No success, please login.

Seems to be rather common practice
comments.name: Jon harald

comments.html: Good feedback Ivan.  Let me see if I can get this opened up.
comments.name: Douglas Gourlay

comments.html:
Ugh, I hate that. Of course, Arista is certainly not without company.

Thank you again for the excellent talk, Doug. And I'll second Ivan's plea. :)
comments.name: stretch

comments.html:
Ugh, I hate that. Of course, Arista is certainly not without company.

Thank you again for the excellent talk, Doug. And I'll second Ivan's plea. :)
comments.name: stretch

comments.html: AFAIK, Juniper always had their documentation in the open. But then again, for a very long time their stance was "we are everything Cisco isn't" ;)
comments.name: Dmitri Kalintsev

comments.html: Not everything that Juniper does can be categorized like this. Juniper genuinely thinks different without regard to Cisco.
comments.name: Andres Iniesta

comments.html:
In this particular case, they obviously followed Cisco's good practices ;)

As Andres said, Juniper does what they think is best.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html:
> Juniper does what they think is best.

Aren't we all? ;)
comments.name: Dmitri Kalintsev

comments.html: Now that you put it in perspective, it does sound like a round circle ;)
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: Let's be serious, they are probably hiding the documentation so Cisco does not get hold of it and use it to pick their products apart.
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html:
You can buy their gear online, directly from their web site. How hard would it be for a competitor to use a dummy company and buy a few boxes?

Wake up to reality. Hiding documentation will never stop your competitors, it will only hurt your sales.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: Riverbed does the same as far as I remember
comments.name: 1001qa

comments.html:
AFAIR, Huawei has guest-level accounts that can access most of the docs. At least in Datacom product line.

Quick check says that datacom section is now open (mostly, no software, no doc cd bundles) even without registration.
comments.name: nld

comments.html:
Gotta agree with Ivan and Stetch. Doug got us all excited..and I appreciate that. Now with some documentation we can make use of what we learned.

Thanks Ivan and Doug.
comments.name: Brandon Carroll

comments.html: Absolutely true. Wrote an update. Thanks for reminding me.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: A lot more Arista documentation is available online now to John Q.Public
